title: UK lawyers' climate pledge reverberates around the world
display_name: UK lawyers' climate pledge reverberates around the world
ab: A commitment by some UK lawyers not to work on fossil fuel schemes has sparked an ethical debate within the profession. While some see the pledge as problematic, however, it could be taken up by peers overseas. A pledge by lawyers not to work on coal, oil or gas projects because of their climate change impacts has reverberated around the UK and beyond. Since the pledge publication on 29th March 2023, more than 170 lawyers have committed to refuse work supporting new fossil fuel projects or that takes action against climate protestors exercising their right to peaceful protest. Prominent UK signatories to the ‘Declaration of Conscience’ include Sir Geoffrey Bindman KC, chair of the British Institute of Human Rights, and Farhana Yamin, one of the architects of the 2015 Paris Agreement on climate change. The declaration was coordinated by Tim Crosland, a lawyer who was disbarred by the Bar Standards Board earlier in the year for causing considerable reputational harm to the profession by leaking a Supreme Court ruling on Heathrow. He said the declaration was the first time in legal history that barristers had engaged in a collective act of civil disobedience, and there had been a “surge of support” for it following publication of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC)'s latest summary of climate science and the imprisonment of members of the campaign group Insulate Britain for contempt of court after talking about climate change in court. The pledge proved controversial in the UK. Some saw it as a meaningless gesture, pointing out that not all of those signing it were able or likely to work in the fossil fuel field anyway. The main issue, however, was that the pledge clashes with the ‘cab rank rule’, which obliges barristers to accept work from any client if they have the time and the professional expertise. Some of the signatories have already referred themselves to the Bar Standards Board, and face the prospect of disciplinary action. Jolyon Maugham KC, founder of the Good Law Project which has brought many lawsuits against the UK government on environmental and social issues, signed the declaration but was surprised by the reaction. “I can understand somebody's weighing up the respective merits of the cab rank rule and the role that lawyers play as midwives to new fossil fuel projects,” he said. “But to assert, as many did, that it is obviously more important than the role of the legal profession in tackling climate change I just think is bananas.” While many barristers defended the cab rank rule, seeing it as key to a fair and functioning justice system, others, such as Richard Moorhead, professor of law and professional ethics at Exeter University, suggested it was time for a more serious debate about the ethics of the legal profession. Such a debate may be about to get into full swing. Last week, Stephen Kenny KC, chair of the Bar Council's Ethics Committee, provocatively stated that barristers can refuse to take on cases as a matter of conscience, in extreme circumstances. The declaration was less controversial among solicitors, who have no such professional restriction. A month after the launch of the declaration, the Law Society published long-awaited guidance on climate change for solicitors, which explains the kinds of risks it raises for solicitor firms and their clients, and what solicitors’ legal responsibilities are when providing advice. It notes that organisations’ targets to cut greenhouse gas emissions “vary hugely in scope, comprehensiveness and ambition”, but should only be considered ‘science-based’ if they are in line with what the latest climate science deems necessary to meet the 1·5°C Paris Agreement goal. The Law Society said that the effects of climate change “are wide-ranging and constantly evolving” and said it would be important for solicitors to be aware of this changing landscape “and its potential impact upon their organisation as well as their legal advice”. Meanwhile, academics working in the fields of criminology, penology, social harm, crime and policing have vowed to lend their full support to climate defenders “who are criminalised by the state”. The declaration is also having an impact further afield. Melinda Janki is involved in several legal challenges against the Guyanese government seeking to block the country's incipient offshore oil industry on the grounds that it will harm the environment and human rights. She has signed the declaration and is intending to invite fellow attorneys in Guyana to follow suit. “I beg my legal colleagues to join me and other lawyers who are on the frontline fighting to uphold the rule of law and protect our countries and planet from the killing effects of fossil fuels,” she said. Tim Hirschel-Burns, Bernstein international human rights fellow at Yale Law School and co-founder of Law Students for Climate Accountability, said he was excited to see growing attention on the role of lawyers and the climate crisis. Although he thinks the UK has been “a little slower” to have these conversations than the US, he said the Law Society guidance provides a powerful model for its American counterparts. Hirschel-Burns added that there was growing interest from UK law students to highlight the legal profession's climate-related responsibilities and declining interest in working for fossil fuel companies. Crosland is now in discussions with lawyers in other countries, including the Netherlands and Italy, about setting up similar declarations.

title: Key concepts to consider when promoting active transportation
display_name: Key concepts to consider when promoting active transportation

author.au_affiliation_raw: Department of Geosciences and Geography, Faculty of Science, University of Helsinki, 00014 Helsinki, Finland

ab: Carmen Jochem and Michael Leitzmann1Jochem C Leitzmann M A call for integrating active transportation into physical activity and sedentary behaviour guidelines.Lancet Planetary Health. 2023; 7: e112-e113Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1) Google Scholar highlighted the importance of promoting active transportation in physical activity guidelines to improve public health and planetary hewalth. In addition to public health guidelines, active transportation has several concepts that should be pursued in parallel. The first concept is multimodality in transportation, which means that people use multiple modes of transportation during a trip, such as walking, cycling, public transportation, with shared mobility services such as bike sharing or car sharing, or other modes for different parts of their trip. Therefore, there is the need to create integrated and interconnected transportation systems that encourage individuals to incorporate physical activity into their daily routines while also reducing their reliance on motorised transportation. The second concept is walkability and cyclability, which refers to the quality of the walking or cycling environment and its ability to support and encourage active transportation.2Wang H Yang Y Neighbourhood walkability: a review and bibliometric analysis.Cities. 2019; 93: 43-61Crossref Scopus (81) Google Scholar This includes creating an attractive and safe environment for pedestrians and cyclists, ensuring good pavement quality and accessibility for those with mobility challenges, providing well lit paths, and avoiding unwanted exposures, such as noise and air pollution. The third concept is individuals' capabilities and opportunities to access and use active transportation modes (ie, accessibility). Accessibility consists of several dimensions, including social, economic, skills-related, physical, temporal, spatial, informational, legal-organisational, mental, and cultural dimensions.3Virmasalo I Hasanen E Defining the accessibility of physical activity: tracing the social dimension.Contesti. Città, Territori, Progetti. 2022; 2: 59-76Crossref Google Scholar The fourth concept is the need for cooperation and interdisciplinary approaches among various sectors.4Muukkonen P Ehnström E Hasanen E et al.Towards equality in physical activity—tools for a multisectoral and interdisciplinary approach in sport planning (in Finnish). University of Helsinki, Helsinki2022Google Scholar One should bring together transportation, urban planning, public health, and other relevant sectors to create integrated and comprehensive approaches to active transportation planning. In summary, improving physical activity guidelines as suggested by Jochem and Leitzmann1Jochem C Leitzmann M A call for integrating active transportation into physical activity and sedentary behaviour guidelines.Lancet Planetary Health. 2023; 7: e112-e113Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1) Google Scholar is one among a suit of potential solutions. Incorporating the concepts introduced here into transportation planning can provide safe and accessible environments for active transportation, which create better local opportunities for people to include active transportation in their daily routines. PM received funding from the Lähiöohjelma 2020–2022, which is coordinated by the Ministry of Environment, Finland (grant number VN/10837/2020). A call for integrating active transportation into physical activity and sedentary behaviour guidelinesAt the 27th Climate Change Conference of the Parties, António Guterres, the Secretary-General of the UN, declared that "we are on a highway to climate hell with our foot on the accelerator".1 This highway leads not only to climate change but also to additional planetary crises, such as pollution and loss of biodiversity, which pose a dire threat to our planet and to the health of current and future generations.2–4 Full-Text PDF Open Access

title: Aiming to deliver more of what matters
display_name: Aiming to deliver more of what matters
ab: It is sometimes hard not to get disheartened if you are concerned about planetary health. Our leaders have consistently failed to recognise the scale of the threat posed by climate change, and the transgression of other planetary boundaries. Public awareness and concern have grown significantly over the last 20 years and government commitments in some areas show promise, but so far this has been wholly insufficient in practice. This isn't just an unwillingness to recognise and prioritise human health and the environment, or even down to effective lobbying of vested interests seeking to preserve the status quo, although both are in operation. More fundamentally than this there seems to be a collective, institutional and systemic failure of imagination, a failure to understand our dependence on the wider world, a failure to recognise the staggering rate and extent of environmental damages and the inequalities in how people are affected, and a failure to recognise the social and economic drivers of these issues. Put simply, much decision making, from individuals to small businesses, to regional and national governments often prioritises the wrong things and habitually fails to directly consider our health or that of the environment. To address this we don't just need piecemeal legislation or more ethical consumers, although these have a place, but we need systems and institutions that routinely consider and strive to prioritise health and the environment. Calls for socio-political transformation abound in reports on biodiversity and climate change. This is a reflection of the size of the environmental challenges we face, but it's rare to hear about truly transformative actions. Rather a more incremental approach is common. It's very understandable that organisations want to start with cheap, easy to implement solutions (often referred to as low hanging fruit) that improve, for example, the carbon intensity of electricity generation by 15%, or reduce plastic packaging by 40%. Such improvements are clearly worthwhile and yet there are limits to what can be achieved with a marginal approach when more substantial changes are required. Implementing the types of changes needed to, for example, completely decarbonise energy generation requires a different approach, and this is often difficult to achieve when the economic context treats these changes as low priorities. In recognition of some of the limiting structural imperatives built into the economy The Council on the Economics of Health for All was formed in 2020 by WHO, with an explicit remit to rethink the economy from a health for all perspective. The council has just published its report Health for All: Transforming economies to deliver what matters. The chair Professor Mariana Mazzucato argues that “States can move from reactively fixing market failures to proactively and collaboratively shaping markets that prioritize human and planetary health”. The report sets out 13 recommendations grouped under four pillars: governing health innovation for the common good, adequately valuing and measuring human and planetary health, financing health, and creating dynamic public sector capacities to achieve health for all. Of these pillars adequately valuing and measuring human and planetary health is the most directly relevant here. The recommendations call for health and wellbeing, health workers and health systems to be treated as a long-term investment, not a short-term cost. The use of legal and financial commitments to enforce health as a human right. The restoration and protection of the environment. And the use of a range of metrics that track progress across core societal values, above and beyond GDP. Most of these integrate well with environmental imperatives. Under the pillar Strengthening public sector capacity the report emphasises “there is a need to recognize that Health for all is not just for health ministries but for all government agencies”. This recognition reflects a broad need for more integrated thinking and policymaking which reaches across traditional knowledge disciplines and sector boundaries. This remains a major institutional learning challenge. The Health for All report contains important insight on how economies might be altered to better serve people and the planet, and it adds to the voices critiquing dominant economic norms. Such recommendations have an intrinsically political aspect and some of them directly relate to long standing political arguments. Whether those in the halls of power are ready to consider such fundamental economic reforms remains to be seen but the importance of these considerations can hardly be overstated.

title: Empower women to grow
display_name: Empower women to grow
ab: On 16th of June 2023, during World Day to Combat Desertification and Drought, representatives of the United Nations Convention to Combat Desertification (UNCCD) warned the international community that women and girls in low- and middle-income countries are suffering the greatest burden of drought, land degradation, and desertification. Climate change and intensive, unsustainable land use, combined with legal and socioeconomic inequalities, mean that women, especially in rural and agricultural settings, are the most exposed to food and water scarcity and to forced migration.

title: Think global, act local: using a translocal approach to understand community-based organisations’ responses to planetary health crises during COVID-19
display_name: Think global, act local: using a translocal approach to understand community-based organisations’ responses to planetary health crises during COVID-19

author.au_affiliation_raw: Institute for Global Health. University College London, London, UK
Ekjut, Jharkhand, India
College of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Sciences, Oregon State University, OR, USA
RAND Corporation, Santa Monica, CA, USA
Casita Huaran, Huaran, Peru
Ekjut, Jharkhand, India
Calor Peru, Cusco, Peru
Institute for Global Development and Social Planning, University of Agder, Kristiansand, Norway
Sauti Dada Africa, Tangulbei, Rift Valley, Kenya
Centre for Corporate Responsibility, Hanken School of Economics, Helsinki, Finland
Sitka Conservation Society, Sitka, AK, USA
Stema, London, UK
Institute for Global Health. University College London, London, UK

ab: Little is known on how community-based responses to planetary health crises, such as the COVID-19 pandemic, can integrate concerns about livelihoods, equity, health, wellbeing, and the environment. We used a translocal learning approach to co-develop insights on community-based responses to complex health and environmental and economic crises with leaders from five organisations working with communities at the front line of intersecting planetary health challenges in Finland, India, Kenya, Peru, and the USA. Translocal learning supports collective knowledge production across different localities in ways that value local perspectives but transcend national boundaries. There were three main findings from the translocal learning process. First, thanks to their proximity to the communities they served, community-based organisations (CBOs) can quickly identify the ways in which COVID-19 might worsen existing social and health inequities. Second, localised CBO actions are key to supporting communities with unique challenges in the face of systemic planetary health crises. Third, CBOs can develop rights-based, ecologically-minded actions responding to local priorities and mobilising available resources. Our findings show how solutions to planetary health might come from small-scale community initiatives that are well connected within and across contexts. Locally-focused globally-aware actions should be harnessed through greater recognition, funding, and networking opportunities. Globally, planetary health initiatives should be supported by applying the principles of subsidiarity and translocalism.

title: Invasive alien species: a rising global threat that needs control
display_name: Invasive alien species: a rising global threat that needs control

author.au_affiliation_raw: Department of Biogeography, University of Bayreuth, 95447 Bayreuth, Germany

ab: Invasive alien species have at last received the global attention required to substantially mitigate their negative effects on biodiversity, health, water, and food security. A new report from the Intergovernmental Panel on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services (IPBES) estimated that such species caused economic loses of US$423 billion globally in 2019. Of the more than 37 000 alien species that have been introduced through various human activities, more than 3500 of these are harmful invasives. Approximately 200 new alien species are recorded annually. A multidisciplinary team of 86 experts from 49 countries, along with more than 200 contributing authors, reviewed more than 13 000 documents to produce the Thematic Assessment of Invasive Alien Species and Their Control for IPBES.1IPBESRoy HE Pauchard A Stoett P Summary for policymakers of the thematic assessment report on invasive alien species and their control of the intergovernmental science-policy platform on biodiversity and ecosystem services. IPBES secretariat, Bonn, Germany2023Google Scholar This assessment was finalised after intense week-long negotiations in Bonn, Germany, and was subsequently approved by 143 governments. Notably, at the onset of these discussions, there was no unanimously agreed-upon terminology for invasive alien species despite 4 years of collaborative effort. This highlights the complexity of the issue. The summary for policy makers now presents an internationally agreed definition while it acknowledges that national and local legislations have varying definitions when addressing biological invasions. The agreed definition for invasive alien species—ie, a species that is either intentionally or unintentionally transported by human activities outside its natural range, is already established and spreads to a new area, and has a negative impact on species and ecosystems in the new region—will hopefully simplify international cooperation for an effective implementation of management and control measures in the future. A very important (and unfortunately, often unique) aspect of these intergovernmental negotiations was the incorporation of diverse values and knowledge systems. These included insights from scientific literature, indigenous populations, and local knowledge holders. Through this inclusive approach, numerous facts and examples of previously overlooked issues related to invasive alien species were brought to light. The assessment emphasises four key messages. First, that invasive alien species are a major threat to nature, nature's contributions to people, and overall quality of life.1IPBESRoy HE Pauchard A Stoett P Summary for policymakers of the thematic assessment report on invasive alien species and their control of the intergovernmental science-policy platform on biodiversity and ecosystem services. IPBES secretariat, Bonn, Germany2023Google Scholar Second the spread of invasive alien species and their impacts are accelerating globally and are expected to intensify in the future.1IPBESRoy HE Pauchard A Stoett P Summary for policymakers of the thematic assessment report on invasive alien species and their control of the intergovernmental science-policy platform on biodiversity and ecosystem services. IPBES secretariat, Bonn, Germany2023Google Scholar Third, the detrimental effects of these species can be prevented and mitigated through effective management.1IPBESRoy HE Pauchard A Stoett P Summary for policymakers of the thematic assessment report on invasive alien species and their control of the intergovernmental science-policy platform on biodiversity and ecosystem services. IPBES secretariat, Bonn, Germany2023Google Scholar And finally, substantial progress to manage biological invasions can be achieved through integrated governance with closer collaboration across sectors and countries.1IPBESRoy HE Pauchard A Stoett P Summary for policymakers of the thematic assessment report on invasive alien species and their control of the intergovernmental science-policy platform on biodiversity and ecosystem services. IPBES secretariat, Bonn, Germany2023Google Scholar Invasive alien species threaten livelihoods, water and food security, economies, and human health. For example, infectious zoonotic diseases such as dengue fever, Chikungunya, Zika, and yellow fever, are spread by invasive mosquito species like Aedes albopictus that originated in southeast Asia but are now established on all continents except Antarctica.1IPBESRoy HE Pauchard A Stoett P Summary for policymakers of the thematic assessment report on invasive alien species and their control of the intergovernmental science-policy platform on biodiversity and ecosystem services. IPBES secretariat, Bonn, Germany2023Google Scholar, 2Diagne C Leroy B Vaissière AC et al.High and rising economic costs of biological invasions worldwide.Nature. 2021; 592: 571-576Crossref PubMed Scopus (498) Google Scholar Invasive alien plants can also impact human health—for example, through the production of highly allergenic pollen causing hay fever, asthma, and allergic dermatitis (eg, Ambrosia artemisiifolia or common ragweed).1IPBESRoy HE Pauchard A Stoett P Summary for policymakers of the thematic assessment report on invasive alien species and their control of the intergovernmental science-policy platform on biodiversity and ecosystem services. IPBES secretariat, Bonn, Germany2023Google Scholar Within the freshwater ecosystem, the invasive water hyacinth (Pontederia crassipes) is able to double its biomass in 1–2·5 weeks, reducing habitat biodiversity through decreasing oxygen levels and thus harming native fish populations and degrading waterfowl habitats.3Global Invasive Species DatabaseSpecies profile: Eichhornia crassipes.http://www.iucngisd.org/gisd/species.php?sc=70Date: 2023Date accessed: October 6, 2023Google Scholar Additionally, invasive alien species represent the most significant threat to natural World Heritage sites, affecting 68 of the 241 sites.4Osipova E Emslie-Smith M Osti wM Murai M Åberg U Shadie P IUCN world heritage outlook 3: a conservation assessment of all natural World Heritage sites.https://portals.iucn.org/library/sites/library/files/documents/2020-035-En.pdfDate: 2020Date accessed: October 15, 2023Google Scholar There are various introductory pathways for these species, for example, through their use for feeding livestock, planting of non-native trees, as ornamental plants or pets, or even accidentally in emergency relief and aid. The invasive parthenium weed—originating in South America and central America and used in enzyme production and as an additive in biogas production—was most likely introduced to India via food grain shipments between 1950s and 1960s from the USA.5Kohli RK Batishj DR Singh HP Dogra KS Status, invasiveness and environmental threats of three tropical American invasive weeds (Parthenium hysterophorus L., Ageratum conyzoides L., Lantana camara L.) in India.Biol Invasions. 2006; 8: 1501-1510Crossref Scopus (210) Google Scholar Serious yield losses (eg, in grain sorghum) even at low densities of the weed are now the consequences for surrounding countries (eg, in Pakistan).6Bajwa A Nawaz A Farooq M Chauhan B Adkins S Parthenium weed (Parthenium hysterophorus) competition with grain sorghum under arid conditions.Expl Agric. 2020; 56: 387-396Crossref Scopus (8) Google Scholar Indigenous Peoples and local communities often have a good understanding of how complex interactions among various drivers facilitate the introduction and spread of invasive alien species in their lands.1IPBESRoy HE Pauchard A Stoett P Summary for policymakers of the thematic assessment report on invasive alien species and their control of the intergovernmental science-policy platform on biodiversity and ecosystem services. IPBES secretariat, Bonn, Germany2023Google Scholar Beyond the aforementioned negative effects, invasive alien species can also restrict access to traditional lands, curtail the mobility of Indigenous Peoples and local communities, and necessitate increased labour for land management.1IPBESRoy HE Pauchard A Stoett P Summary for policymakers of the thematic assessment report on invasive alien species and their control of the intergovernmental science-policy platform on biodiversity and ecosystem services. IPBES secretariat, Bonn, Germany2023Google Scholar Moreover, these species can result in the loss of traditional livelihoods, knowledge, and cultural practices among these communities.1IPBESRoy HE Pauchard A Stoett P Summary for policymakers of the thematic assessment report on invasive alien species and their control of the intergovernmental science-policy platform on biodiversity and ecosystem services. IPBES secretariat, Bonn, Germany2023Google Scholar The IPBES report encapsulates the vast body of existing knowledge and highlights the knowledge gaps concerning invasive alien species, thereby laying the foundation for concerted interventions across the affected sectors. A substantial challenge lies in the willingness of governments to earnestly address the issue of these species. It is imperative that governments undertake sustainable and effective measures to manage and control invasive alien species promptly. Alarmingly, assessments reveal that 83% of countries lack specific national legislation or regulations concerning such species.1IPBESRoy HE Pauchard A Stoett P Summary for policymakers of the thematic assessment report on invasive alien species and their control of the intergovernmental science-policy platform on biodiversity and ecosystem services. IPBES secretariat, Bonn, Germany2023Google Scholar Even when such legislation is in place, such as the Invasive Alien Species list of the European Union (regulation 1143/2014), it can lack effectiveness. This is particularly evident when species are listed based solely on their potential impact on biodiversity or ecosystem services, relegating impacts on human health or economy as mere secondary considerations. A case in point is the mosquito vector Ae albopictus, which remains unlisted due to the absence of evidence showing its negative effect on biodiversity or ecosystem services (as per personal communication with the invasive alien species team of the EU commission). To address these issues, IPBES recommends several strategic actions, including coordination and collaboration across international and regional frameworks; the development of effective national implementation strategies; shared efforts, commitments and understanding of specific roles of all actors; improving policy coherence; engaging with governmental sectors, the industrial sphere, scientific communities, Indigenous Peoples, local communities, and the broader public; funding and promoting innovative research and environmentally conscious technology; and strengthening information systems, infrastructure, and data sharing.1IPBESRoy HE Pauchard A Stoett P Summary for policymakers of the thematic assessment report on invasive alien species and their control of the intergovernmental science-policy platform on biodiversity and ecosystem services. IPBES secretariat, Bonn, Germany2023Google Scholar Under a business-as-usual scenario, IPBES anticipate a 36% increase in alien species by 2050 compared with 2005.1IPBESRoy HE Pauchard A Stoett P Summary for policymakers of the thematic assessment report on invasive alien species and their control of the intergovernmental science-policy platform on biodiversity and ecosystem services. IPBES secretariat, Bonn, Germany2023Google Scholar Furthermore, the economic repercussions of biological invasions are predicted to quadruple every decade.1IPBESRoy HE Pauchard A Stoett P Summary for policymakers of the thematic assessment report on invasive alien species and their control of the intergovernmental science-policy platform on biodiversity and ecosystem services. IPBES secretariat, Bonn, Germany2023Google Scholar Proactive and decisive action is crucial to curtail the adverse effects of invasive alien species. The greater than 60% success rate of biological control programmes aimed at invasive alien plants and invertebrates should inspire future endeavours.1IPBESRoy HE Pauchard A Stoett P Summary for policymakers of the thematic assessment report on invasive alien species and their control of the intergovernmental science-policy platform on biodiversity and ecosystem services. IPBES secretariat, Bonn, Germany2023Google Scholar It is vital to recognise the nexus between biodiversity, and the health of environment, ecosystems, animals, and humans as we shape our strategies moving forward. I received travel grants from the University of Bayreuth, Germany, to attend author meetings of the IPBES nexus assessments and the IPBES10 plenary.

title: Quantifying climatic and socioeconomic drivers of urban malaria in Surat, India: a statistical spatiotemporal modelling study
display_name: Quantifying climatic and socioeconomic drivers of urban malaria in Surat, India: a statistical spatiotemporal modelling study

author.au_affiliation_raw: Departamento de Ciencias Biológicas and Grupo de Investigación en Biología Matemática y Computacional BIOMAC, Universidad de los Andes, Bogotá, Colombia
Barcelona Supercomputing Center, Barcelona, Spain
Center for Spatial Data Science, University of Chicago, Chicago, IL, USA
Urban Health and Climate Resilience Center of Excellence (UHCRCE), Surat, India
Vector Borne Diseases Control Department, Surat Municipal Corporation, Surat, India
author.institution_display_name: Sardar Vallabhbhai National Institute of Technology Surat

author.au_affiliation_raw: Surat Municipal Corporation, Surat, India
author.institution_display_name: Sardar Vallabhbhai National Institute of Technology Surat

author.au_affiliation_raw: Department of Biology and Department of Environmental Studies, New York University, NY, USA

ab: Cities are becoming increasingly important habitats for mosquito vectors of disease. The pronounced heterogeneity of urban landscapes challenges our understanding of the effects of climate and socioeconomic factors on mosquito-borne disease dynamics at different spatiotemporal scales. Here, we quantify the impact of climatic and socioeconomic factors on urban malaria risk, using an extensive dataset in both space and time for reported Plasmodium falciparum cases in the city of Surat, northwest India.We analysed 10 years of monthly P falciparum cases resolved at three nested spatial resolutions (seven zones, 32 units, and 478 worker units) with a Bayesian hierarchical mixed model that incorporates the effects of population density, poverty, relative humidity, and temperature, in addition to random effects (structured and unstructured). To reduce dimensionality and avoid correlation of covariates, socioeconomic variables from survey data were summarised into main axes of variation using principal component analysis. With model selection, we identified the main drivers of spatiotemporal variation in malaria incidence rates at each of the three spatial resolutions. We also compared observations to model-fitted cases by quantifying the percentage of predictions within five discrete levels of malaria risk.The spatial variation of urban malaria cases was stationary over time, whereby locations with high and low yearly cases remained largely consistent across years. Local socioeconomic variation could be summarised with three principal components accounting for approximately 80% of the variance. The model that incorporated local temperature and relative humidity together with two of these principal components, largely representing population density and poverty, best explained monthly malaria patterns in models formulated at the three different spatial scales. As model resolution increased, the effect size of humidity decreased, whereas those of temperature and the principal component associated with population density increased. Model predictions accurately captured aggregated total monthly cases for the city; in space-time, they more closely matched observations at the intermediate scale, with around 57% of units estimated to fall in the observed category on average across years. The mean absolute error was lower at the intermediate level, showing that this is the best aggregation level to predict the space-time dynamics of malaria incidence rates across the city with the selected model.This statistical modelling framework provides a basis for development of a climate-driven early warning system for urban malaria for the units of Surat, including spatially explicit prediction of malaria risk several weeks to months in advance. Results indicate environmental and socioeconomic covariates for which further measurement at high resolution should lead to model improvement. Advanced warning combined with local surveillance and knowledge of disease hotspots within the city could inform targeted intervention as part of urban malaria elimination efforts.US National Institutes of Health.

title: Mind the Gap
display_name: Mind the Gap
ab: Another critical year has almost passed, and the climate outlook is depressingly familiar. 2023 is almost certain to be the hottest year on record with a truly exceptional September breaking previous temperature records by a record margin. The signs of climate impacts on society, and health in particular are becoming clearer all the time — no longer abstract modelled projections, but the lived realities of people around the world.

title: Preserving forests means culture change
display_name: Preserving forests means culture change
ab: Halting global deforestation is a cornerstone of climate change mitigation and securing natural biodiversity for the future. Healthy primary forests store and sequester large amounts of carbon, have huge ecological importance, and support the lives and livelihoods of billions of people, but deforestation continues at pace globally and land-use change contributes 12–20% of annual greenhouse gas emissions. The international community has set ambitious goals to end and reverse deforestation by 2030; with a leading policy lever being direct payments to countries, communities, or landowners to leave forested land intact. However, a new report from The Energy Transition Commission, a think tank, suggests that stopping deforestation in tropical regions through direct payments could be substantially more costly than previously estimated and financially unsupportable in the long term, without wider societal changes. Reducing emissions from deforestation and degradation or REDD policies encompass payments under private carbon markets and offsetting services and country-to-country agreements. The total money from all public and private schemes might be around $2·3 billion annually; however, the Commission report estimates that the actual cost of direct payments to stop deforestation in the most threatened tropical regions could be from $130 billion to $900 billion annually. Maintaining this level of direct payment in the long term would be unsustainable. Instead, the report argues that $130 billion of finance per year is needed up to 2030, as a stop gap measure to halt tropical deforestation, and at the same time to invest in longer term solutions, including changing consumer demand, developing more environmentally friendly business models, and strengthening laws and enforcement to protect forest. Planetary health researchers have important roles to play in understanding, quantifying, and communicating the value of intact, biodiverse forest for human health and wellbeing, and in advancing understanding of how social, cultural, and economic incentives can be changed to drive more sustainable systems and choices. The single largest driver of tropical deforestation and degradation is land clearance for agricultural commodities. The creation of pasture for beef alone accounts for 40% of tropical deforestation. If the consumption of animal foods continues to grow alongside global incomes, in line with current trends, an additional 400 million hectares of wild ecosystem could be converted by 2050. Research and policy efforts to transition higher income populations toward more sustainable diets will be vital to reduce deforestation. On tackling illegal deforestation, there has been some positive news. The re-election of Lula da Silva as Brazilian presented in January 2023 came with pledges to end illegal logging and curb deforestation. This is a welcome change after deforestation reached a 15-year peak in the Amazon following the anti-conservation leadership of former president, Jair Bolsonaro. Policing deforestation effectively and upholding the rights of indigenous peoples—who steward 80% of remaining biodiversity—is difficult and must be combined with eliminating the demand for the products of illegal deforestation. However, the efficacy of voluntary actions has been mixed. Many large financial firms and institutions, for example, remain invested in companies whose products are linked to illegal deforestation, despite signing pledges to eliminate deforestation from their investments. On 19th April 2023 the EU Parliament voted to adopt a law to prevent the sale of any products in the bloc linked to deforestation or degradation of natural forest. Such laws could force higher standards, but scrutiny and pressure will have to come from all parts of society. In the healthcare and research communities, providers and institutions should increasingly ensure that their procurement removes deforestation related products from supply chains. Employers and pension funds should be encouraged to make their practices and investments consistent with ending global deforestation and with the scientific evidence around the health and societal benefits of doing so. Once lost, primary forests, especially in tropical areas, are difficult to recover. Payments to preserve forests are an important part of the solution, particularly in the short term, but they are no silver bullet for forest protection. We need a wider cultural shift toward recognizing the full value of intact forests and other natural ecosystems; this will be hard won, but is vital if we are to stop undermining our own wellbeing.

ab: The climate crisis is also a crisis of language, communication, and translation.1 At the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change meeting in Shanghai in January, 2001, for example, Saudi Arabia refused to support a motion saying that it is likely that man-made greenhouse gases have contributed substantially to global warming over the previous 50 years. This refusal was "on the grounds that 'substantial' did not translate into Arabic".2 Although language can be weaponised in ways that ultimately harm planetary health, this Comment tells the story behind a series of projects between scientists at the Met Office (Exeter, UK) and creative researchers as well as health professionals at the University of Exeter, to harness the power of words to tell more hopeful and emotionally engaged stories; we are sharing practice and insights should others wish to adopt and adapt them.

title: Promising the Earth
display_name: Promising the Earth
ab: When we think about and discuss progress towards the sustainable development goals (SDGs), for example, how effectively we are cutting carbon emissions, halting biodiversity loss, or eradicating poverty, there is a tension between a desire to recognise progress and the need to acknowledge how far we still have to go. Focussing on progress can help shift dialogue from being problem focussed to solution orientated; this can be energizing and facilitate movement building. By contrast focussing on how much more we still need to do is frequently seen as negative, uninspiring, potentially anxiety inducing and even defeatist, all of this may be true to an extent and yet to measure progress we need to know how far we are from our goals as well as how far we have got from the startling line.

ab: Health crises have raised awareness of the links between forests and human health. For example, outbreaks of Ebola virus and hypotheses about the origins of SARS-CoV-2 have highlighted the risk of zoonotic spillover events from forest-dwelling animals.1,2 Likewise, forest fires in Australia (2019–20), the Amazon rainforest (2019), and southeast Asia (2015) have drawn attention to the respiratory health effects on populations exposed to smoke and haze.3 Other links between forests and health, such as the role of forests in mitigating natural disasters4 and regulating infectious disease vectors,5 are well established but less well known outside the scientific community.

title: Youth activists' perspectives on climate, sexual and reproductive health and rights, and gender inequality
display_name: Youth activists' perspectives on climate, sexual and reproductive health and rights, and gender inequality

author.au_affiliation_raw: Engajamundo, Sao Paulo, Brazil
Engajamundo, Sao Paulo, Brazil
UN Women, New York, NY 10017, USA
UN Women, New York, NY 10017, USA

ab: Generation Equality is a global multistakeholder partnership mechanism advocating for a wide range of issues, including the gender and climate justice agenda. Convened by UN Women in 2020, Generation Equality is based on the landmark 25th anniversary of the 1995 Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action on the promotion of women's rights. In this Comment, we build on a Generation Equality side event held during the Sixty-Sixth Commission on the Status of Women in 2021, which placed a spotlight on the neglected but highly interconnected climate, sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR), and gender inequality crises.

title: Playing politics with the future
display_name: Playing politics with the future
ab: Since the Climate Change act of 2008—the first legally binding climate mitigation commitment of any nation—The UK has been something of a climate policy leader. This is not to say that the UK is doing enough, but in a field of slow movers it has been a front runner. One of the reasons this has been possible is because, unlike in many other countries, addressing climate change has had cross-party political support. However, in a speech on 20th September UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak announced a series of policy changes which weakened or delayed UK emissions reduction measures. This policy rollback occurred while other world leaders were attending the UN ‘climate ambition’ summit in New York. This sudden policy change is not only extremely short sighted, leaving yet more work to be shouldered in the future, but also endangers the UK's longstanding cross party-political consensus on climate change, while the conservative party consider what tactics may help them in the next general election. The substance of the policy changes were to generally reduces or delay mandates on electric cars, and electrification of building heating, as well as building insulation requirements and energy infrastructure, among other things. In his speech the Prime Minster emphasised these measures as an “honest” approach to reaching net-zero while removing unreasonably high costs from “hard-working British people”. However, there are a number of problems with this narrative. Firstly, delaying and watering down policies that were already, according to the Committee on Climate Change, at risk of failing to deliver on the government's 2050 target clearly makes that target still harder to achieve and important interim targets more difficult too. More fundamentally it is senseless to discuss the costs of climate policies without considering the costs of inaction and it is unfortunate that this kind of one-sided argument is still accepted and goes largely unchallenged in mainstream media coverage. Furthermore, while climate policies do have a cost, the way they are paid and who bears them is not inevitable, but the direct result of political choices and priorities. Even if we only considered current household costs, previous rounds of green policy cuts and delays have been estimated in a report form the Climate and Energy Intelligence Unit to have cost UK households up to £1750 on bills in 2022, compared with the savings that could have been made through green investments. To make the kinds of investments required to achieve net zero emissions the private sector requires a loud and consistent signal. Sudden policy changes like those announced by the Prime Minister reduce investor and developer confidence which increases the cost of capital and the overall cost of decarbonisation. These decisions undermine the UK's ability to capitalise on the opportunities of green jobs and industry. In short, these policies seriously damage the UK's ability to meet its legal decarbonisation commitments, risk increasing, rather than decreasing, household costs and send a damaging message about the UK's commitment to its climate obligations. Perhaps even more concerning, this move seems likely to be the start of an attempt to politicise climate policies which could, if the public can be sufficiently divided, further delay climate action in the UK. Currently the UK public remain broadly supportive of climate mitigation policies, even while living through a cost of living crisis. Whether that high level of support will make divisive politics less successful remains to be seen but this is certainly cause for concern and something those concerned about a healthy planetary future need to understand and guard against.

title: Weathering child displacement
display_name: Weathering child displacement
ab: Extreme weather-related events are major causes of forced migration, and it is widely acknowledged that climate change is and will increasingly drive more frequent and severe adverse weather events and add to the risk of displacements. Children are particularly vulnerable to the negative effects of displacement. If separated from their carers or forced to travel alone, children are put at risk of injury and deprivation from potential long journeys over unsafe terrain and of mistreatment, abuse, or even trafficking by criminals. Being displaced can also cut children off from vital services like healthcare and education and jeopardize their longer-term development and wellbeing. If temporary accommodation conditions for displaced children are poor then they can face undernourishment, exposure to harsh environmental conditions or infectious disease outbreaks, and an absence of emotional support in traumatic circumstances. During a weather disaster a child's family might lose property and livelihoods, damaging their future chances to resettle and earn an income. Despite the heightened dangers, disaggregated data on child-specific displacements from extreme weather conditions are rarely available. A report co-produced by UNICEF, the Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre, and Patrick J. McGovern Foundation, has for the first time estimated the number of children who are displaced globally by floods, droughts, storms, and wildfires, and how that picture could develop as the climate warms. An estimated 43·1 million children were internally displaced due to a weather-related disaster between 2016–2021—with the vast majority driven by flooding or storms. Risk modelling suggests that over the next 30 years riverine flooding could displace 96 million children, cyclonic winds 10·3 million, and storm surges 7·2 million. The risk to children from these extreme events is not evenly spread. Although, for example, the largest overall numbers of children displaced by flooding and storms were in China, India, and the Philippines—which have large populations and well-developed disaster evacuation responses—countries with lower capacity to respond to disasters, such as Somalia and Sudan, and small island nations, such as Vanuatu and Dominica, have seen the largest proportion of their child populations displaced. The findings of this report highlight that children are most vulnerable to lasting disruption from weather-related disasters in already precarious contexts, where economic, political, environmental, and historical dangers overlap. Sudan, for example, has been affected by heavy flooding in 2022, and again in 2023 amid an ongoing civil war that has displaced 2·6 million children. Nonetheless, the evidence is becoming clearer that climate change is amplifying the risks from extreme weather events and worsening humanitarian disasters. In 2022 the devastating floods in Pakistan affected more than 33 million people, leading to fatalities, wide destruction of buildings, infrastructure, livestock and crops, and the mass displacement of people. A rapid attribution study suggests that the record-breaking monsoon rainfall preceding the floods was likely made more intense by a warmer global climate. Serial droughts in east Africa since 2020—which now raise the risk of famine and further displacements—are estimated to have been made 100 times more likely in our anthropogenically-warmed global climate. In addition to acute pressures, longer-term climate driven risks—such as food insecurity, water scarcity and poor quality, extreme heat, desertification, and sea level rise—will likely become increasingly important drivers of child displacement in the future. Even under optimistic mitigation scenarios where global warming is kept below 2°C the climate change impacts will leave millions of children vulnerable to displacement. Investment in adaptation and resilience building could prevent displacement or lessen its impacts in some contexts, and a just means of funding that work in poorer countries could be through a loss-and-damages arrangement (although administering such a fund has already been stalled). While some degree of greater exposure to extreme weather events is now inevitable, poor outcomes for children are not. Adaptation as a global community demands a compassionate approach to children displaced by climate disasters that ensures their safe movement, continuity of health and education, and aid in resettling or in moving on, so that a young person's entire future is not undone by the misfortune of being caught in an increasingly common calamitous event.
